alert.note: Alert for Cook; Lake (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued March 11 at 1:29PM CST until March 11 at 2:30PM CST by NWS Duluth
info.description: The National Weather Service in Duluth MN has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Cook County in northeastern Minnesota... Northeastern Lake County in northeastern Minnesota... * Until 230 PM CST. * At 129 PM CST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from 12 miles northwest of Hovland, to 7 miles north of Grand Marais, to 7 miles northeast of Lutsen, to 12 miles southwest of Eagle Mountain, to Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, moving southeast at 30 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts up to 30 mph. SOURCE...Satellite and webcams. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. * This includes Minnesota Highway 61 between Grand Portage and Lutsen and the Gunflint Trail between Grand Marais and Gunflint Lake. Locations impacted include... Grand Marais, Gunflint Lake, Grand Portage, Lutsen, Hovland, Eagle Mountain, Sea Gull Lake, Little Saganaga Lake, Alpine Lake, Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness North of the Gunflint Trail, southeastern Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Pine Lake, Tom Lake, Bearskin Lake, Grand Portage Reservation, Kekekabic Lake, Phoebe Lake, North Lake, Judge Magney State Park, and Watab Lake. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Reduce your speed and turn on headlights! During snow squalls, the visibility may suddenly drop to near zero in whiteout conditions. There is no safe place on a highway when a snow squall hits. Visibility and traction are immediately lost in whiteout conditions, making it difficult or impossible to slow down and avoid stopped vehicles. Delay travel or safely exit the highway before the snow squall arrives.
